titleStmt.title: Dissolution in Ceramic Systems: I, Molecular Diffusion, Natural Convection, and Forced Convection Studies of Sapphire Dissolution in Calcium Aluminum Silicate

analytic.title: Dissolution in Ceramic Systems: I, Molecular Diffusion, Natural Convection, and Forced Convection Studies of Sapphire Dissolution in Calcium Aluminum Silicate

div.p: Measurements of the rate of dissolution of single crystals of sapphire in molten CaO-A1203-SiOz slag from 1340" to 1550°C under conditions of molecular diffusion, free convection, and forced convection reveal that the rate of dissolution was controlled by transport in the molten silicate. The results were self-consistent in that the independently calculated apparent binary diffusion coefficient agreed well for all three cases. This binary diffusion coefficient at temperatures above 1450°C coincided remarkably well with that of the tracer diffusion coefficient for the silicon ion.
For a number of reasons the significance of this agreement should not be overestimated.

div.head: I, Introduction
div.p: ATE of dissolution are important for many ceramic proc-Applications include the corrosion of refractories R by molten slags and glasses, the rate of conversion of batch to glass in the glassmaking process (which is governed by the dissolution rate of the most refractory particles), and the firing of a ceramic body in which a liquid phase develops. These examples and the following discussion refer specifically to dissolution of a solid in a liquid. I n principle, however, the discussion applies equally well to dissolution of a gas by a liquid, a liquid by a liquid, a solid by a solid, and even components of a liquid by a solid, all of which occur in ceramic systems. The purpose is to examine the factors that determine the rate of the dissolution process, and toward this end the system sapphire-Ca0-Al203-SiO2 slag was selected for an experimental investigation.

div.head: The System
div.p: The equilibrium diagram CaO-Al203-Si02 reveals' that at all temperatures above 1380°C there are stable liquids along the CaSi03-A1203 binary at all compositions from 0.10 weight fraction of alumina to the alumina liquidus. From the ternary equilibrium diagram, a pseudo binary can be constructed that shows the liquidus composition, and hence the saturation concentration, expressed as weight iraction of solute as a function of temperature. This curve is shown in Fig. 1 and represents the source of all information used on solubility.

Density data necessary for calculations of partial volume, for conversions of dynamic to kinematic viscosity, and for calculation of the driving force for certain free convection flows arc plotted in Fig. 2 from the data of Barrett and Thomas. These investigators also measured the surface energy of the same compositions and found that i t increased with increasing A1203 concentration. Ko~akevich's~ and esses. Machin and Yee's4 measurements of viscosity over a wide range of temperature and composition along with the density data just given allow the kinematic viscosity to be well described along the alumina-calcium silicate binary. This information, summarized in Fig. 3, is useful directly for calculations of dissolution rates where convection is important and indirectly for extrapolation of diffusivity data along the binary. Tracer diffusion coefficients for oxygeq6 calcium,e silicon,e and aluminum7 have been measured at several temperatures a t compositions close to the binary with about 20 wt% Also3; these results are summarized in Fig. 4.

div.head: Glass Composition
div.p: The glass for this investigation was made from glass sand, calcium carbonate, and aluminum hydroxide. The composition varied during the experiments, but periodic analyses were made to keep track of such variations. The results hereafter reported are without correction from a composition showing no more than a + l % variation from the nominal alumina content. Results are extrapolated to take into account changes in solubility resulting from the variation in alumina concentration up to +3%; no larger deviations occurred. Analyses indicated variations in the calciumsilicon ratio of about 1.0 to 0.8 during the experiments. There is no obvious basis for correction for this change, and therefore it represents a source of possible error, but indications are that the effect is small.

div.head: IV. Experimental Apparatus and Procedure
div.p: A Globar-heated furnace that could attain 1600°C for short periods and 1550°C for long times was constructed in two interlocking halves that separated horizontally, permitting adjustment and alignment of the system to be made with the furnace halves separated before heating. The molten silicate solvent was contained in an alumina crucible 3 in. in diameter and 5 in. deep with a platinum liner. Details of the crucible and liner and several specimen arrangements are shown in Fig. 6. Temperature variations within the crucible did not exceed 1" a t 15OOOC.

To study dissolution rates of stationary specimens a sapphire cylinder of measured diameter,* nominally 4.5 mm, was cemented to a hollow ceramic and inserted through the muffle tube to a position within the crucible but above the melt, held there for a few minutes until the specimen attained melt temperature, and then immersed to a depth of about 12 mm.

As shown in Fig. 6, the effects of the melt-ambient interface on the dissolution process could be eliminated by wrapping the solute cylinder with platinum foil in this region. After a measured period of immersion the solute specimens were raised rapidly to a position near the top of the muffle tube, quenching any adhering solvent and stopping the dissolution process. After removal from the furnace, the adhering slag was removed with either 50y0 hydrofluoric acid or concentrated hydrochloric acid. The change in solute diameter was then measured with a micrometer at several places along the solute axis with results reproducible to within f 0.0002 in. On some specimens small irregularities on the surface were noted, but these were avoided during measurement.
For the study of dissolution under forced cqnvection, a welldescribeds flow that affects dissolution in a known way was produced by rotating a disk face of the sapphire in the slag.

The experimental arrangement for rotating the sapphire consisted of an upper-drive assembly and a specimen assembly. The upper-drive assembly included a constantspeed motor with appropriate timing belts and gears to rotate either of two upper shafts a t speeds from 300 to 5400 rpm. The bearings from the upper shafts were mounted in cross members whose rotation about the center post permitted either upper shaft to be swung above the outside of the furnace, where the specimen could be aligned for concentricity.

div.head: J. S. Machin and Tin
div.p: The upper shafts could be moved up or down in their bearings.

A support plate held the specimens from above. The dissolving specimens were short cylindrical sapphire rods nominally 12.5 mm long and 7 mm in diameter with a central hole in one end in which was cemented a sapphire shaft 3 mm in diameter. The sapphire shaft was secured to the drive shaft with a connector having six setscrews; adjustment of these screws permitted the eccentricity of the specimen to be kept within a tolerable valueg (0.030 in.) despite considerable camber in the sapphire shafts. After the specimen assembly was aligned and the length o€ the specimen was accurately measured, the specimen was introduced through the muffle tube and held in the crucible above the melt surface. The upper shaft was then swung into a position directly above the melt, aligned vertically, fitted into the connector, and secured. The specimen was lowered into the melt by sliding the upper shaft downward in its bearings, and rotation of the specimen was started immediately after its immersion.

Change in length of the specimens was measured after the removal of adhering solvent. Greater precision of measurements was attained when only the lower disk face was immersed during dissolution (Fig. 6, lower leff).

div.head: V. Molecular Diffusion
div.p: For stationary specimens it would be expected that the initial rate of transport would be governed by molecular diffusion, i.e., diffusion in the absence of fluid flow produced by hydrostatic instabilities or by forced convection, A typical set of measurements for stationary sapphire cylinders dissolving in calcium aluminum silicate slag of 21 wt% alumina is shown in Fig. 7. div.head: VI. Free Convection
div.p: As dissolution of a stationary specimen proceeds, i t is likely that a hydrodynamic instability will develop either from density differences or (if an ambient-slag interface is exposed) from surface tension differences between the alu- mina-saturated slag and the bulk slag. This is called free or natural convection and results in a virtually time-independent or steady-state rate of solution for an infinite slab. It was found that in free convection the pattern and the amount of dissolution under otherwise identical conditions were dependent on whether or not the specimen was exposed to the slag-ambient interface. This is clear in Fig. 8, which shows traced profiles of two cylindrical sapphire specimens immersed in slag of weight fraction of alumina of 0.21 for 1200 seconds a t 156OOC. The much higher corrosion, particularly in the region of the slag-ambient interface in the case where the surface is exposed and the knowledge that the surface energy of CaSi08-A1208 slag increases with increasing Al203 content, suggests that surface forces cause a natural convection that markedly increases the amount of dissolution near a free surface. * Since solutions are available only for the case where density difference is the driving force for free convection, all further experiments were conducted with the sapphire protected near the slag-ambient interface to allow comparison of the results with calculations.
The results of a series of free convection experimcnts a t 155OoC and with a bulk weight fraction o€ alumina of 0.21 are shown in Fig. 9.
It is clear that after a relatively short induction period in which molecular diffusion kinetics prevail the rate of dissolution becomes nearly independent of time.

div.head: VIII. Discussion
div.p: All the experimental results are well explained under the premise that the dissolution of sapphire in calcium aluminum silicate slag is controlled by mass transport in the liquid; even when the transport rates are greatly enhanced by rotating a disk a t 5400 rpm, its rate of dissolution is still correctly predicted by the assumption that mass transport is rate determining. The self-consistency of the molecular diffusion, free convection, and forced convection experiments is indicated by the close agreement of prediction and measurements shown in Fig. 9 and by the agreement of the calculated diffusion coefficient values, DZO, which are summarized in Fig. 12 where it is seen that a t all temperatures the calculated diffusion coefficients from the different experiments agree well with one another.

The independently measured values for the tracer diffusion coefficient of aluminum and silicon ions in slags of nearly the same composition are also shown on this figure. At the higher temperatures, i.e., above 145Q"C, the calculated coefficients are close to the measured values for silicon tracer diffusion. One should not place great importance on this coincidence, because in addition to the lack of precision of the data itself and the lack of confirmation of the Stokes-Einstein relation used in the present calculations, no corrections were made for possible tracer correlationz5 and possible variations of activity coefficient with concentration in the system.26 Finally it is noted that the problem is indeed a matter of multicomponent diffusionz7 and the relations between tracer diffusion coefficients and the cross terms in multicomponent diffusion are not evident at this time.

At lower temperatures the divergence of the calculated binary diffusion coefficient and the measured values for silicon ion diffusion is noticeable. The discrepancy may be explained in part by the fact that when the temperature is low, the solubility is low and slight errors in concentration have more effect on rates of solution. Also, as seen in is no longer the primary phase in contact with the bulk slag below 1380°C.

IX. Conclusions I t has been demonstrated by several quantitative tests that the dissolution of sapphire in calcium aluminum silicate slag is governed by mass transport in the liquid. Molecular diffusion, natural convection, and forced convection experiments provide a group of data that is self-consistent. The calculated effective binary diffusion coefficient for the dissolution process agrees rather closely with the independently measured tracer diffusion coefficient for silicon except at low temperatures where additional information is needed and where other factors may cloud the results.
